application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: We develop multiresolution models for analyzing and visualizing two-dimensional flows over curvilinear grids. Our models are based upon nested spaces of piecewise defined functions defined over nested curvilinear grid domains. The nested domains are selected so as to maintain the original geometry of the inner boundary. We first give the refinement and decomposition equations for Haar wavelets over these domains. Next, using lifting techniques we develop and show examples of piecewise linear wavelets over curvilinear grids.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Multiresolution models are proving to be very valuable in the analysis and visualization of scientific data. Multiresolution models based upon the ideas of wavelets have been developed and applied for a variety of different types of data sets in scientific visualization and computer graphics. (See [1], [3], [6], [7], [8], and [9]). In this paper we present some new results on multiresolution models for two-dimensional vector fields defined over curvilinear grids. Curvilinear grids are often associated with vector fields due to the methods for numerically solving the equations which mathematical model flows. Figure 1.1 gives an overview of the context of our problem. We assume that we have a discrete vector field known at the vertices of a curvilinear grid. This is the raw data and represents the highest level of our model. We want to compute a lower resolution model that represents the flow field well and then visualize this model with the idea that eliminating the clutter of higher order details and features will reveal certain overview aspects of the flow field. There are a number of methods for visualizing flow fields. See [5] for a survey on these methods. In this paper, we use topological graphs, but what technique is used for visualizing the flow field is not an issue of this paper. The multiresolution model is the focus of this paper and any technique could be used to view the models we discuss here. We choose topological graphs because they work well in the context of the static nature of the method of presenting this paper. (For a detailed discussion on the techniques used to compute the topological graphs of the figures of this paper see [4].) Not only do we want to compute lower resolution approximations to the flow field, but we also want to maintain sufficient information which will allow the efficient reconstruction of the flow field and, in particular, we would like to efficiently do this reconstruction locally so as to facilitate efficient zoom in and zoom out for perusal of the flow field.

The potential benefits of multiresolution models for data over curvilinear grids are further illustrated in Figure 1.2. In the sequence on the left starting at the bottom and moving up we are zooming out without changing the resolution. Already, at the middle image, it is so cluttered with the tangent curves of the topological graph that it extremely difficult to see or understand any aspects of the flow. In the right sequence the resolution is changing as we zoom out for an overview. Here we can easily see the points of attachment and detachment on the rear of the car body. The techniques that we describe here allow for the rapid computation of these different resolution models and for the efficient local reconstruction so as to allow the user to freely peruse the data by zooming in or out and adding and deleting detail as desired. This is illustrated in Figure 1.3. The lower right image is the original data and the other images show the ability to add and eliminate detail at any location desired. Our methods are based upon the basic idea of wavelets. Wavelets, in their most basic and fundamental form, apply to samples of a univariate signal taken at equally spaced increments. Developing multiresolution models with all the important and beneficial aspects of wavelets for the domains associated with many real world data sets is a formidable challenge for researchers. The work presented here is step in this direction.

div.head: Curvilinear Grids and Nested Domains
div.p: Before we proceed with the description of our multiresolution models, we need to describe and introduce some notation for curvilinear grids. A curvilinear grid is defined by a pair of geometry arrays, ( , ), , , ; , , x y i n j m , ,

. We assume that the data of the geometry array is such that each of the quadrilateral cells is well defined in that the polygon delineating its boundary is nonintersecting. In addition, we usually have an "inner boundary" defined which is delineated by a sequence of vertices of the grid, ( , ),
x y ij IB ij ij ∈ . We assume that this bounding polygon is simple and closed and that the inner boundary region is simply connected. ; @ .

The flow will be assumed to be zero on the entire inner boundary. Our multiresolution models will be based upon functions which are defined in a piecewise manner over a sequence of nested domains. This sequence of nested domains is generated by a vertex removal process which is illustrated in Figure 2.2. Each of the cells at a lower level maintains all the outer edges of the cells contained within it from the previous level. This method of generating a sequence of domains guarantees two important properties. The first is that the domains are nested so that
div.formula: C C C C C ij k i j k i j k i j k i j k − − − − − = 1 2 2 2 12 2 2 1 2 12 1 , ,, , U U U
div.p: . This nested property guarantees that piece-wise defined function spaces will also be nested by inclusion. That implies that any approximation at level k − 1 is contained in the collection of approximations at level k . The second important property of this type of nested domain is that the inner boundary is preserved throughout the sequence of domains. Usually in applications with an inner boundary, the interesting and important aspects of the flow occur near the inner boundary and this geometry is a very important aspect of the problem at hand. For this reason, we felt it to be unacceptable to utilize a sequence of nested domains and subsequent approximations which altered this basic property of the flow.

div.head: Haar and Linear Wavelets
div.p: In order to convey the ideas of our wavelet approximations we show the details for moving through two levels approximations for a small case as illustrated in Figure 3 We can represent an arbitrary piece-wise constant function over this curvilinear grid as . This leads to the final expansion have replaced the previous coarse approximation.
div.formula: F P ( ) = λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ φ λ
div.p: A general step in this decomposition is accomplished by successively processing groups of four terms associated with four cells at a particular level. We now give the details of how this is done. 10 01 11 This completes the description of the Haar wavelets over the nested domains described in Section 2. In Figure 3.4 we show yet another example. Using the techniques of the lifting scheme of [10], it is possible to extend to biorthogonal linear wavelets. More discussion on this can be found in [9]. The linear wavelets are generally more efficient at approximating smoothly varying data. We include an example in Figure 3.5. We can compare these results with those of Figure 3.4 based upon the Haar wavelets. The top center image in both figures is the same and is a topological graph of the original data. We can see that the topological graph of the first level approximation for the linear wavelets is almost identical to the original data indicating that almost nothing is lost by compression to this resolution. But much of the "high frequency" information is lost at the first level of the Haar wavelet approximation.
